I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Climate- and Disaster-Resilient Irrigation and Drainage 
Modernization in the Vakhsh River Basin Project. The report also describes proposed technical 
assistance (TA) for Support to Operation and Maintenance and Financial Sustainability of Water 
Resources Infrastructure, and if the Board approves the proposed grant, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The project is the first gender equity themed irrigation and drainage (I&D) investment of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Tajikistan. The project will enhance climate resilience, 
water productivity, and the income of female and male farmers by modernizing selected areas of 
the Yovon I&D system, located in Khatlon province of the lower Vakhsh river basin. The project 
will introduce (i) climate- and disaster-resilient modernization of prioritized I&D infrastructure, 
(ii) streamlined institutions and systems for effective planning and operation and maintenance 
(O&M) of I&D infrastructure, and (iii) policies and strategies for gender equality to enhance 
women’s participation in land and water management. About 6,700 farmers in the Yovon I&D 
system, of whom 12% are female, and 4,200 homestead (kitchen) gardens in the core project 
area,1 which are mostly managed by women, will benefit from improved water service delivery, 
energy savings, and application of climate-smart technologies in I&D. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Reliance on agriculture. Tajikistan is a landlocked and mountainous country with a 
population of 9.3 million, of which 44.7% was employed in agriculture and 26.3% lived below the 
poverty line in 2019.2 The country has a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of $822. It has 
a narrow economic base reliant on limited raw products (cotton and aluminum) and remittances.3 
Male laborers from the rural areas constitute about 95% of Tajik migrant labor.4 In 2020, 
remittances  comprised  26.7%  of  GDP  and  agriculture  23.8%  (footnote  3).  The  country  is 
vulnerable to economic shocks resulting from fluctuations in regional demand. The agriculture 
sector grew by 9.3% from 1997 to 2004 and by 6.4% from 2005 to 2014. This decline was caused 
by low agricultural productivity. With only 7% of land being arable, limited land per capita of 0.1 
hectares (ha), and underdeveloped agriculture, Tajikistan has one of the highest levels of food 
insecurity in the world. It ranks 85th out of 113 countries for food insecurity.5 Undernourishment 
rates are high (30% in 2017), with a disproportionately high percentage of undernourished 
women.6 Food insecurity is expected to increase because of limited capacity to respond to 
climate- and earthquake-induced shocks that will adversely affect agricultural production. 
 
 
1  The core project area refers to the irrigable area of four water users associations (WUAs). These are (Istiklol 2010, 
Chorgul-2012, Norin, and Obi Yovon). The total core area is 9,830 ha(25%) of the entire system’s command area of 
40,360 ha. Secondary and tertiary I&D modernization will be focused in the core area. 
2  World Bank. Open Data. Employment in agriculture (% of total employment) (modeled International Labour 
Organization estimate) (accessed 8 November 2021); and ADB. Poverty Data: Tajikistan (accessed 8 November 
2021). 
3  World Bank. Open Data. Personal remittances, received (% of GDP) - Tajikistan (accessed 8 November 2021). 
4  N. Mukhamedova and K. Wegerich. 2017. The feminization of agriculture in post-Soviet Tajikistan. Journal of Rural

2 
4.  Feminization of agriculture. Tajikistan ranked 137th out of 153 countries on the global 
gender gap index, scoring low on women’s economic participation and political empowerment.7 
The high level of male outmigration has led to a substantial increase in women’s responsibilities 
in agriculture. The proportion of women in the agricultural labor force increased from 54% in 1999 
to  more  than  75%  in  2020.8 Women  operate  homestead  gardens  (cultivating  fruits  and 
vegetables) to meet their nutritional and food security needs. Dekhan (farmer) farms headed by 
women produce cotton, wheat, and fodder crops. Women also manage water collection and 
allocation within the household for productive and domestic uses, and hygiene maintenance. 
Despite women’s crucial role in agriculture and as primary water users, they do not have equal 
access to knowledge and inputs for improved agricultural productivity. They also have a limited 
role in decision-making on water management because of their low representation in water users’ 
associations (WUAs). This is because membership is dependent on having a land certificate, 
which few women farmers possess (footnote 4). In the social and gender analysis conducted for 
the project, women farmers comprise only 20% of the membership of 17 WUAs in the Vakhsh 
river basin, with no women in leadership structures. 
 
5.  Vulnerability to climate change and natural hazards. The Vakhsh river is the major 
tributary of the Amu Darya, which is the largest in Central Asia. Tajikistan is highly vulnerable to 
the adverse effects of climate change. Projections indicate that temperatures will increase by up 
to 2 degrees Celsius by 2050. Increases in the annual probability of meteorological drought are 
predicted from the current 3% to more than 25% by 2050. There is likely to be a shift in the Vakhsh 
river flow regime with high flows occurring earlier in the year, in May instead of June or July, due 
to the earlier melting of snow and ice. Changes in climatic conditions are projected to have severe 
effects on agriculture in Tajikistan. Temperature increases leading to heat stress and increased 
water demand for key crops, combined with increased drought incidence, will significantly reduce 
agricultural yields. The impacts of climate change will increase extreme flood events, resulting in 
higher risks of landslides and mudflows and potentially costing many lives and livelihoods. 
 
6.  Tajikistan is highly vulnerable to natural hazards, including earthquakes, floods, and 
landslides, potentially reducing irrigation system performance and agriculture productivity. From 
1992 to 2016, disasters affected more than 80% of the population and resulted in $1.8 billion in 
economic losses.9 The earthquake hazard risk for the project area is rated high. This means that 
by the 2070s, there is more than a 20% chance of a potentially damaging earthquake.10 An 
earthquake in 2001 damaged the irrigation infrastructure in the Yovon I&D system, resulting in 
loss of irrigation for 11,724 ha of land. It also affected 56,000 people and 65,000 livestock.11 In 
2021, mudslides  destroyed  houses  and  bridges,  and  partially  damaged  the  Vakhsh  canal. 
Farmers and government agencies lack the knowledge and capacity to adapt agricultural and 
irrigation practices to changing climatic conditions and to natural hazards. 
 
7.  Aging infrastructure. Irrigation consumes about 85% of the annual total water resources 
of Tajikistan. The total irrigated area is 761,523 ha, with one-third of land supplied with irrigation 
water by pumps. The I&D systems, which were developed prior to the country’s independence in 
1991, have deteriorated or are entirely defunct. The government’s Agency for Land Reclamation

and Irrigation (ALRI) estimated in 2012 that 6,000 kilometers (km) of inter-farm canals, 60% of 
I&D wells, and more than one-third of pump stations require major repairs. More than 53,000 ha 
of land are in poor ameliorative condition because of deteriorated drainage. 
 
8.  The performance of I&D systems is further constrained by (i) severe underfunding of 
O&M;12 (ii) inflexible irrigation systems that do not allow farmers to adjust their irrigation schedules 
in response to climate-induced changes in water availability; (iii) inefficient collection of irrigation 
service fees (ISFs);13 (iv) limited capacity of WUAs to pay higher ISFs; (v) weak capacity and 
service orientation of the ALRI; (vi) low capacity to complete repairs in a timely manner after 
disaster events; and (vii) fragile WUAs with low skills, lack of knowledge of climate-smart 
agricultural practices, and limited inputs for improved agricultural productivity. Deteriorated I&D 
facilities and poor on-farm water management result in low crop yields, excessive water losses, 
waterlogging, and soil salinization. 
 
9.  Water sector reforms and institutions. The Government of Tajikistan undertook sector 
reforms in 2013 that assigned water resources planning and regulation to the newly created 
Ministry of Energy and Water Resources. Water resources infrastructure management, service 
provision, and O&M were assigned to the ALRI. Regional and district ALRI offices are responsible 
for O&M of the main I&D systems, and for providing I&D services to WUAs. A new Water Code 
assigns to the government the functions of setting tariffs for water supply services and designating 
sources and procedures for financing O&M of national water facilities,14 leaving little decision-
making latitude for ALRI. A new WUA Law was signed in 2020.15 It defines the economic, 
organizational, and legal based of WUAs. It gives WUAs right and responsibility to operate and 
maintain hydraulic structures and equipment and authorizes the creation of a union of WUAs. 
 
10.  COVID-19 pandemic. Tajikistan has experienced significant adverse economic and social 
impacts from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. GDP growth dropped from 7.5% in 
2019 to 4.5% in 2020. Unemployment rose to 6.1% by the end of 2020 from 2.0% in early 2020. 
COVID-19 had significant impacts on remittances, tourism, and trade, with remittances falling by 
14.8% in the first half of 2020.16 The strengthened climate and disaster resilience within the project 
area  will  contribute  to  post-COVID-19  recovery  through  crop  diversification  and  increased 
agricultural production, leading to improved livelihoods and food security. 
 
11.  Opportunities  and  lessons.  ADB  and  other  development  partners  support  I&D 
improvement in the country through investment projects and TAs. These are delineated across 
the four major river basins with complementary activities such as river basin planning and WUA 
strengthening. ADB has extensive experience in I&D and flood risk management in the Pyanj river 
basin. It is also the first development partner to invest in I&D infrastructure in the Vakhsh river 
basin. Lessons from I&D projects in Tajikistan include (i) interlinking capacity building of water 
management institutions with infrastructure improvements; (ii) providing flexible, equitable, and 
reliable  service  delivery  to  farmers  to  adapt  to  current  and  future  climate  variabilities;  (iii) 
addressing cost recovery for sustainable O&M at the outset of the project; (iv) identifying and 
introducing water management technologies that are appropriate for local conditions; and (v) 
organizing targeted gender activities for women’s empowerment in irrigated agriculture.

and sources and procedures for financing O&M water facilities, including I&D systems.

12.  Assistance of ADB and other development partners. ADB has worked closely with 
other development partners to coordinate project activities. The World Bank-financed Second 
Public Employment for Sustainable Agriculture and Water Management Project supports the ALRI 
and WUAs for improved water management in the Kofarnihon river basin. It has also initiated a 
water resources information system within the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources and the 
ALRI. The World Bank- and European Union-funded Zarafshon Irrigation Rehabilitation and 
Management Improvement Project complements ADB initiatives in I&D by increasing farmers’ 
skills in crop diversification and improved infrastructure. 
 
13.  Strategic alignment. The project aligns with the following key government strategies: (i) 
the National Water Strategy, 2016–2030, which defines food security and increased employment 
opportunities  as  strategic  development  goals,  and  emphasizes  efficient  allocation  of  water 
resources between competing sectors of the economy; (ii) the Water Sector Reform Program, 
2016–2025, which aims to increase the effectiveness and efficiency of water management and 
boost national agriculture production; (iii) the National Disaster Risk Reduction Strategy, 2019–
2030, which aims to decrease and prevent existing and new disaster risks by strengthening the 
national  capacity  in  disaster  risk management;17 and  (iv)  Tajikistan’s  Nationally  Determined 
Contribution submitted to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, in which 
reduction of vulnerability to impacts of climate change through adaptation is a priority.18 
 
14.  The project supports ADB’s country partnership strategy for Tajikistan, 2021–2025.19 It will 
support Tajikistan in climate and disaster resilience for productive agriculture and improved 
natural resources management. It will promote gender equity for increased access of women to 
productive activities and improved incomes. It also aligns with the United Nations Sustainable 
Development  Goals;  the  Climate  Change  Operational  Framework,  2017–2030;  and  ADB’s 
Strategy 2030.20 Specifically, the project aligns with the Strategy 2030 operational priorities of (i) 
addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental  sustainability;  (iv)  promoting  rural  development  and  food  security;  and  (v) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity.21 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
15.  The project is aligned with the following impact: food security and people’s access to good 
quality nutrition increased.22 The project will have the following outcome: climate and disaster 
resilience, water productivity, and income of male and female farmers increased in selected areas 
of the Yovon I&D system.23 
 
16.  Output  1:  Climate-  and  disaster-resilient  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure 
modernized. This will modernize the Yovon I&D system to increase reliability and flexibility in 
irrigation service delivery, comprising (i) modernized and seismic shock-proofed main and branch 
canals and associated structures; (ii) provision of energy-efficient pump installations; (iii) erosion

17.  Output 2: Climate-adaptive and gender-responsive management and operation of 
irrigation and drainage systems strengthened. In order to support climate resilience, this will 
include (i) establishment of a single system management entity to manage irrigation water control 
and remote monitoring systems, and enhancement of farmers’ resilience to climate change 
impacts; (ii) creation of a union of WUAs, with women comprising at least 10% of the leadership, 
to provide improved services to WUAs and farmers; (iii) operationalization of a cashless payment 
system with volumetric metering and asset inventory for the core project area to enable flexible 
and on-demand irrigation; (iv) introduction of modern climate-smart agriculture and irrigation 
practices with on-farm land management and conservation techniques; and (v) adoption of 
climate-adaptive labor- and water-efficient systems for high-value crops to be managed by women 
in their homestead lands. 
 
18.  Output 3: Policy for sustainable water management strengthened. This will include 
(i) development of options for climate-adaptive and sustainable O&M funding and formulation of 
a revised tariff structure, and (ii) development and adoption of a gender strategy for the ALRI and 
WUAs. This is to strengthen women’s access to land and improve female participation in water 
management. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
19.  ADB will introduce innovative approaches in I&D with high-level technologies comprising 
(i) satellite-based measurement of water productivity, crop production, and irrigation scheduling; 
(ii) a buried pipe system with metering for increased control of irrigation water use; (iii) remotely 
operated flow control and monitoring via a supervisory control and data acquisition system; (iv) 
innovative I&D asset management and O&M planning; and (v) transparent cashless payment for 
irrigation services. As ADB’s first gender equity investment in I&D in Tajikistan, the project will (i) 
increase women’s engagement in management and access to services of WUAs; (ii) implement 
efficient farm-level and homestead irrigation practices, and climate-smart agricultural support 
services to women farmers; and (iii) mainstream gender policies in the ALRI and WUAs. 
 
20.  The Asian Development Fund (ADF) 13 Thematic Pool for Supporting Disaster Risk 
Reduction and Climate Adaptation will fund seismic proofing of main and branch canals and 
associated structures ($3.2 million) by upgrading and stabilizing critical infrastructure to reduce 
risk of failure because of earthquakes. It will further fund climate change adaptation measures 
($3.4  million)  to  support  on-demand  irrigation  systems,  including  introduction  of  modern 
technologies.24 The grant will also support (i) improved institutional arrangements for O&M of the 
Yovon I&D system, (ii) capacity building for climate-smart agriculture at the farm and homestead 
levels, and (iii) erosion reduction. This innovative climate- and disaster-resilient approach may be 
replicated within the country and more broadly in the Central and West Asian region.

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
27.  The TA aims to improve project asset and financial management. It will also strengthen

8 
O&M cost recovery of the Yovon I&D system and related institutions such as the ALRI and the 
WUAs. It will reduce the burden on the national budget and contribute to improved sector 
governance and financial sustainability. The TA will deliver two outputs: (i) an asset and financial 
management system (AFMS) designed for improved and efficient and sustainable infrastructure 
O&M, and (ii) an AFMS installed for reduced operational and financial sustainability risks and 
increased transparency of O&M fund allocation. Staff will also be trained in its operation and in 
troubleshooting. The key activities comprise (i) review of current O&M practices in the irrigation 
sector, (ii) assessment of the existing AFMS in the ALRI, (iii) design of an AFMS adapted to local 
conditions, (iv) procurement and installation of an AFMS, and (v) training of key stakeholders on 
AFMS operation. The financing plan, detailed activities, cost estimates, and implementation 
arrangements are in the attached TA.29 
 
28.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The TA will be implemented from December 2021 
until 2024. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of access to data and 
information, counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
29.  Rigorous technical due diligence was undertaken during project preparation.30 It included 
assessing major risks and constraints to achieving the project outputs and outcome, identification 
of priority works, measures for climate change resilience and adaptation, and mitigation of water-
related disasters. Satellite remote sensing established command and cropped areas, and water 
productivity for major crops (cotton and wheat). Remote sensing was used for calculating crop 
water requirements and water accounting. The TA undertook topographic surveys and prepared 
advanced feasibility designs for the main system infrastructure and selected pumping stations.  
 
30.  The due diligence confirms that (i) sufficient water will be available in the targeted area; 
(ii) a modernized irrigation system will be designed with flexibility to accommodate climate 
variations; (iii) the use of buried pressurized piped distribution systems is an appropriate solution 
for steeply sloping land and for increased water efficiency, flexibility in conveyance, and reduction 
of system O&M costs; and (iv) O&M practices and institutional arrangements will be improved. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
31.  The project economic and financial analyses estimated the incremental benefits and costs 
for the projects under the with-project and without-project scenarios to assess economic viability. 
Benefits include improved crop intensity, yield and quality of production, and diversification of 
crops because of reliable flexible water delivery. The economic internal rate of return for the 
project is 19.9%, which is higher than the economic cost of capital of 9.0%, confirming the project’s 
economic viability.31 The household financial incremental income from the project is $188/ha 
excluding returns to labor and $195/ha including returns to labor. Sensitivity analyses confirmed 
that the investment is robust with regard to increased investment costs; reduced benefits (reduced 
product prices and yield increases, cropping intensity, and/or reduced diversification to higher-

C.  Sustainability 
 
32.  The financial analysis and evaluation concluded that financial sustainability risk is high 
because of low O&M budget allocations, heavy dependency on central government support, and 
limited capacity to manage and plan system O&M. ADB will provide support through the attached 
TA to (i) improve the ALRI’s overall O&M, asset, and financial management; (ii) train ALRI staff 
to strengthen O&M planning and monitoring; and (iii) introduce efficient farming and water 
management practices that will optimize the long-term operation of the modernized system for 
project beneficiaries. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
33.  The  financial  management  assessment  concluded  that  the  pre-mitigation  financial 
management risk for the ALRI and the SICLRC and/or PIG is high because of (i) a weak project 
financial management system; (ii) limited financial management capacity of the ALRI and SICLRC 
and/or PIG staff; (iii) absence of an internal audit function; (iv) weak asset management and 
inventory controls; (v) overall poor governance structure; (vi) poor oversight and accountability 
and responsibility for financial structures; and (vii) weak integrity, transparency, ethics, and 
accountability mechanisms.33 A time-bound  financial  management  action  plan  (FMAP)  was 
agreed with the government and detailed in the financial management assessment in the PAM 
(footnote  25).  The  FMAP  aims  to  ensure  that  the  ALRI  takes  stronger  responsibility  and 
accountability over the project and is directly involved in contract signing and overall project 
financial management. 
 
34.  Project procurement risk assessment rated procurement risk high for the ALRI. It is also 
assessed as high for SICLRC and/or PIG because of (i) implementation delays in past projects, 
and (ii) the ALRI’s weak procurement capacity. Procurement risk mitigation measures were 
identified through a strategic procurement planning exercise and were built into the project 
procurement strategy. Value for money shall be achieved by (i) proposing contract packages to 
attract both international and national bidders based on market assessment; (ii) open competitive 
bidding using the single-stage: one envelope bidding procedure for most of the packages to 
enhance efficiency and transparency; and (iii) engaging the PIC using advance contracting to 
provide detailed design, supervision, and implementation support. 
 
35.  The  assessment  recommended  that  project  implementation  arrangements  include 
qualified and strengthened SICLRC, PIG and PIOs, with support from the PIC. ADB and the ALRI 
will jointly undertake reviews of the project at least once a year. They will assess project progress 
and performance, including procurement transactions; performance of contractors, suppliers, and 
consultants;  monitoring  and  reporting  of  project  assets;  and  identification  of  issues  and 
constraints. ADB and the ALRI will determine any necessary remedial actions and adjustments. 
 
36.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the ALRI. An FMAP has been formulated, including measures requiring 
the  ALRI  to  set  up  adequate  transparency,  accountability,  anticorruption,  and  integrity 
mechanisms. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the 
PAM (footnote 25) and the FMAP.

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
37.  In 2019, the average poverty rate within the project area was 32.8%, higher than the 
national average of 26.3%. Female participation in the labor market was 31.3% compared to 
52.8% for men.34 Two-thirds of women in Tajikistan are engaged in the agriculture sector, but 
many work under precarious conditions as informal agricultural workers. Cotton remains the major 
crop, though farmers have started shifting to the production of other crops such as vegetables 
and fruits. Forced child labor in cotton cultivation is not evident in Tajikistan.35 
 
38.  The project is categorized as gender equity theme and is designed to address gender 
disparities in access to irrigation and agricultural services, decision-making in land and water 
management, and program planning and implementation. A project-specific gender study carried 
out during project preparation revealed that women have fewer opportunities than men to 
participate in irrigation-related decision-making, and less access to knowledge, information, 
training, and employment (footnote 8). Because of the outmigration of men, women bear a 
disproportionate share of the burden of irrigating crops. This is true especially at the end of the 
irrigation season, when water is not easily available for small-scale agricultural production. 
Women mostly operate homestead gardens that often do not receive adequate irrigation water 
supply because of limited or a lack of appropriate delivery infrastructure and poor irrigation 
scheduling. WUAs tend to prioritize irrigation water supplies for farms rather than homestead 
gardens. 
 
39.  The project will have significant positive impacts on women. It will increase the income of 
6,700 farmers, about 12% of whom are women. It will also increase the production of vegetables 
produced by homesteads managed by women and install modernized and climate-resilient 
irrigation systems that will benefit dekhan farms and homesteads managed by women to improve 
crop productivity. The project will also strengthen women’s engagement in the management and 
access to services of WUAs. This will be achieved by increasing their membership in WUAs, 
placing them in leadership roles, and creating committees that will provide dedicated services to 
women farmers and agricultural workers. It will include improving their understanding of their legal 
rights and access to financial services for developing enterprises. Women’s access to support 
services  will  also  be  developed  through  capacity  building  activities,  and  the  provision  of 
agricultural inputs and simple farm equipment. The gender strategy to be developed for the ALRI 
and WUAs will guide gender mainstreaming in (i) systems, policies, and program implementation, 
including recruitment, promotion, and training of personnel; (ii) the design and delivery of services; 
and (iii) collection and reporting on information about land and water management.36

42.  The existing (limited lengths of) buried I&D asbestos cement pipelines within the project 
area are in poor condition. Their upgrading is considered the key environmental issue. An 
asbestos management plan (AMP) was prepared as part of the EMP. During the detailed design, 
asbestos-containing materials (ACMs) in the system such as pipes, pumps, gaskets, and flumes 
will be identified and recorded in an asbestos investigation report, and the exact ACM volume will 
be determined. The handling, removal, transport, and safe disposal (where necessary) will be 
included in the asbestos abatement plan. For the ACMs to remain in place, there will be an 
asbestos O&M plan. The asbestos investigation report, asbestos abatement plan, and asbestos 
O&M plan will together form the updated AMP. The EMP and the AMP require the contractor to 
assign an asbestos supervisor and at least five asbestos workers, an environmental safeguards 
officer, and a health and safety officer. They will be trained on asbestos management by the 
international environmental specialist mobilized as part of the team of the PIC. 
 
43.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). Social safeguards due diligence has confirmed 
that the works for the main system will be conducted strictly within the existing right of way and 
state land where no private assets, encroachers, nor any other third-party land uses have been 
identified.39 No involuntary resettlement impacts are expected. Modernization of the I&D tertiary 
systems over the core project area of 9,830 ha comprises about 564 km of buried pipeline. A 
maximum of 282 km of pipeline will be accessed for cleaning of wells and replacement of 
pipelines. This will affect standing crops and trees within the farmland and homestead land. The 
final pipeline sections where access is required will only be known after a detailed investigation 
of the condition of the pipeline is conducted during detailed design. After the investigation is 
completed and the detailed design is prepared, screening will be conducted again to confirm the 
final involuntary resettlement impacts. It is estimated that a maximum of 147 ha of privately used 
land and 1,550 people may be temporarily affected. No physical displacement or severe impacts 
are expected. A land acquisition and resettlement plan will be prepared in accordance with the 
land acquisition and resettlement framework prepared by the ALRI,40 and fully implemented 
before displacements occur. During the project preparation stage, public consultations were 
conducted and an estimated budget for compensation was calculated. All the social safeguard 
requirements  and  entitlements  of  affected  peoples,  together  with  the  result  of  the  public 
consultation and budget estimate, are documented in the land acquisition and resettlement 
framework. 
 
44.  Indigenous peoples (category C). There are no indigenous peoples in the project area, 
as per the definition of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
45.  The government has agreed that the project will adhere to ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy  (2001),  internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards,  and  the  country’s  labor 
legislations.41

metadata.Subject:
The project will enhance climate resilience, water productivity, and the income of female and male farmers by modernizing selected areas of the Yovon I&D system, located in Khatlon province of the lower Vakhsh river basin. The project will introduce (i) climate- and disaster-resilient modernization of prioritized I&D infrastructure, (ii) streamlined institutions and systems for effective planning and operation and maintenance (O&M) of I&D infrastructure, and (iii) policies and strategies for gender equality to enhance women’s participation in land and water management.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2021 is provided for the ADB project 53109-001 in Tajikistan.
metadata.Title: Climate- and Disaster-Resilient Irrigation and Drainage Modernization in the Vakhsh River Basin Project: Report and Recommendation of the President
